intro: Scleria pratensis, commonly known as the marsh arrowgrass, is a flowering plant native to wetland environments in temperate regions. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, often forming dense clusters. Its slender, grass-like stems are often adorned with small, triangular leaves. Scleria pratensis produces spikelets that contain tiny, wind-pollinated flowers, contributing to its ecological role in wetland ecosystems.
